## Types of Analyses: Basic Terminology

\begin{itemize}
\item \textbf{Primary analysis} \\
is the original analysis of data in a research study. It is what one typically imagines as the application of statistical methods.

\item \textbf{Secondary analysis} \\
is the re-analysis of data for the purpose of answering the original research question with better statistical techniques, or answering new questions with old data.

\item \textbf{Research Synthesis} \\
set of qualitative/quantitative methods to combine data or findings of previous research
\end{itemize}

\begin{flushright} \scriptsize (Card, 2012; Glass, 1976)\end{flushright}


## Research Synthesis

\LARGE

\begin{itemize}
  \item Narrative Review
  \item Systematic Review
  \item Meta-analysis
\end{itemize}

\begin{flushright} \scriptsize (Uman, 2011, \textit{J Can Acad Child Adolesc Psychiatry}) \end{flushright}


## Narrative Reviews

\begin{itemize}
  \item Tend to be mainly descriptive
  \item Do not involve a systematic search strategy; hence, they could be prone to selection bias…
  \item … however, narrative reviews are often published by important authors, and they are easy to read. Furthermore, they provide a broader range of subtopics: Thus, it may be very useful for an initial search stage!!!
\end{itemize}

\scriptsize

Suggested Journals
\begin{itemize}
  \item \textit{Annual Review of Psychology}
  \item \textit{Personality and Social Psychology Review}
  \item \textit{Psychological Review}
  \item \textit{Annual Review of Organizational Psychology and Organizational Behavior}
\end{itemize}

## Systematic Reviews

\begin{itemize}
  \item Tend to be mainly descriptive (as narrative reviews), or they show \textbf{simple descriptive analyses}
  \item However, the search strategy involves \textbf{a detailed and replicable plan}
  \item The topic is \textbf{narrower} than narrative reviews
\end{itemize}

\scriptsize

Suggested Journals
\begin{itemize}
  \item \textit{Clinical Psychology Review}
  \item \textit{Health Psychology Review}
  \item \textit{Review of Educational Research}
  \item \textit{The Leadership Quarterly}
\end{itemize}

### Some examples of Systematic Reviews

\begin{itemize} \footnotesize
\item \textbf{Developmental Psychology} \\
Aldrup, K., Carstensen, B., \& Klusmann, U. (2024). The role of teachers’ emotion regulation in teaching effectiveness: A systematic review integrating four lines of research. \textit{Educational Psychologist, 59}(2), 89-110. \url{https://doi.org/10.1080/00461520.2023.2282446}
\item \textbf{Organizational Psychology} \\
Robertson, I. T., Cooper, C. L., Sarkar, M., \& Curran, T. (2015). Resilience training in the workplace from 2003 to 2014: A systematic review. \textit{Journal of Occupational and Organizational Psychology, 88}(3), 533-562. \url{https://doi.org/10.1111/joop.12120}
\item \textbf{Personality Psychology/Clinical Psychology} \\
Perinelli, E., \& Gremigni, P. (2016). Use of social desirability scales in clinical psychology: A systematic review. \textit{Journal of Clinical Psychology, 72}, 534-551. \url{https://doi.org/10.1002/jclp.22284}
\item \textbf{Psychometrics} \\
van de Schoot, R., Winter, S. D., Ryan, O., Zondervan-Zwijnenburg, M., \& Depaoli, S. (2017). A systematic review of Bayesian articles in psychology: The last 25 years. \textit{Psychological Methods, 22}(2), 217-239. \url{https://doi.org/10.1037/met0000100}
\end{itemize}


## Meta-Analyses

\Large

Group of statistical methods used for

\begin{itemize}
  \item summarize the results of primary studies;
  \item analyze the degree of heterogeneity of these studies;
  \item explain the differences found between studies.
\end{itemize}

---

\small

\begin{itemize}
  \item Analyses are \textbf{more advanced} than those used for systematic reviews (Correlation Coefficient, Cohen’s d, GLM, multitrait-multimethod matrices, SEM)
  \item Here too, search strategy involves \textbf{a detailed and replicable plan}. Hence, the starting point of a meta-analysis is a systematic review
  \item The topic is narrower than systematic reviews: Usually the focus is obtaining an \textbf{effect size} (``the amount of something that might be of interest''; Cumming, 2012, p. 34), called \textbf{meta-analytic effect size}
\end{itemize}

\begin{center} \textcolor{green}{\underline{ESCI chapters 5-6 Jul 4 2011.xlsm} [sheet: CIs and replication]} \end{center}

## History of Meta-Analyses

\small

In 1976, \textbf{Gene V. Glass} coined the term Meta-Analysis.  

In 1977, \textbf{Smith \& Glass} published a meta-analysis of the effectiveness of psychotherapy from 375 studies, showing that psychotherapy was effective and that there is little difference in effectiveness across different types of therapies.

In late 1975, \textbf{Schmidt \& Hunter} wrote a meta-analysis on personnel selection, but did not immediately submit it for publication, because of an APA award participation. They won that award, but as a result, their first meta-analysis article was not published until 1977 (Schmidt \& Hunter, 1977).

\tiny

Suggested Literature:  
-   Glass, G. V. (2015). Meta-analysis at middle age: A personal history. \textit{Research Synthesis Methods, 6}(3), 221-231.  
-   Schmidt, F. L. (2015). History and development of the Schmidt–Hunter meta-analysis methods. \textit{Research Synthesis Methods, 6}(3), 232-239.

\toprule
\textbf{Step} & \textbf{Aim} \\ \midrule
1 & Articulating one or more Research Questions for your systematic review or meta-analysis \\
2 & Define Inclusion and Exclusion criteria \\
3 & Identifying Relevant Literature \\
4 & Coding study characteristics in a table \\
5 & Extracting \textit{effect sizes} (e.g., correlations, standardized mean differences) and standard errors from individual studies, and presenting them visually \\
6 & Artifact correction \\
7 & Computing the meta-analytic effect size (\textit{fixed-effects} vs. \textit{random-effects} model) \\
8 & Assessing statistical Heterogeneity among effect sizes (e.g., $Q$ statistic and $I^2$ index) \\
9 & Explaining Heterogeneity among effect sizes (\textit{Moderator Analyses} and \textit{Meta-Regression}) \\
10 & Assessing the Risk of Publication Bias (\textit{moderation analysis} between published vs. unpublished studies; \textit{Funnel Plot}; Egger’s linear regression method; Begg and Mazumdar’s rank correlation method; Failsafe Number; \textit{Trim and Fill method}) \\
11 & Publishing the Systematic Review or Meta-analysis following PRISMA guidelines \\
\bottomrule
\end{tabular}
\caption{Steps and Aims in a Systematic Review or Meta-analysis}
\end{table}

\textbf{Backward Searches}  
After accumulating a set of studies for potential inclusion in your meta-analysis, you should read these articles completely searching for \emph{cited studies} (i.e., in \emph{References}) that might be relevant for your review that you did not identify through your other strategies.  

\textbf{Forward Searches}  
To find \emph{studies that cite} the studies you have (\emph{“cited by”} option in Google Scholar).

6) Artifact corrections (e.g., unreliability)

\footnotesize

\begin{itemize}
  \item “individual primary studies [may] report effect sizes among imperfect measures of constructs, not the construct themselves” (Card, 2012, p. 127).
  \item Especially in Work and Organizational Psychology (due to the influential work of Hunter and Schmidt), it is important to correct for artifacts, such as unreliability. This requires the \textbf{collection of reliability indices (e.g., Cronbach's alpha)} for each measure used in meta-analytic purposes.
  \item See Schmidt \& Hunter (2015), Card (2012, Chapter 6), Morris (2023, pp. 229–239), and two webpages from the \href{https://www.metafor-project.org/doku.php/tips:hunter_schmidt_method}{\texttt{metafor}} and \href{https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/psychmeta/vignettes/overview.html}{\texttt{psychmeta}} packages.
\end{itemize}

7) Computing \textbf{mean effect size} (fixed-effects model)

\only<1>{
\footnotesize
Equations from Card (2012, Eq. 8.1-8.4)
\begin{itemize}
  \item Weight for study $i$, $w_i = \frac{1}{SE_i^2}$, where $SE_i$ is the standard error of the effect size estimate for study $i$.
  \item Weighted mean effect size, $\overline{ES} = \frac{\sum (w_i ES_i)}{\sum w_i}$, where $w_i$ is the weight for study $i$; $ES_i$ is the effect size estimate from study $i$.
  \item Standard error of the mean effect size, $SE_{\overline{ES}} = \sqrt{\frac{1}{\sum w_i}}$
  \item Statistical significance test of the mean effect size, $z = \frac{\overline{ES}}{SE_{\overline{ES}}}$.
\end{itemize}
}

\only<2>{
\footnotesize
Problems with fixed-effects
\begin{itemize}
  \item The fixed-effects model is \textbf{often unrealistic} in the context of meta-analysis.  
  \item It assumes that all studies included in the analysis estimate a common true effect size, \textbf{disregarding any between-study heterogeneity} that may arise due to differences in study populations, methodologies, or contextual factors.
  \item Therefore, it is often preferred to use the \textbf{random-effects model}, since it accounts for between-study heterogeneity by assuming that the true effect size varies across studies rather than being fixed.
  \item This model incorporates \textbf{an additional variance component} to capture differences in study characteristics, improving the generalizability of findings and providing more realistic estimates when study populations, methodologies, or contexts are diverse.
\end{itemize}
}

7) Computing \textbf{mean effect size} (random-effects model)

\small

A random-effects model in meta-analysis can be estimated in four general steps:

\begin{enumerate} 
  \item Estimating the heterogeneity among effect sizes $Q$ (equation reported in Step 8),
  \item Estimating population variability in effect sizes $\tau^2 = \frac{Q - (k - 1)}{\left( \sum w_i \right) - \left( \frac{\sum w_i^2}{\sum w_i} \right)}$
  \item Estimating the random-effects weights of study effect sizes $w_i^* = \frac{1}{\tau^2 + SE_i^2}$
  \item Using these random-effects weights to estimate a random-effects mean effect size $\overline{z_r} = \frac{\sum (w_i^* z_r)}{\sum w_i^*}$ and standard errors $SE_{\overline{z_r}} = \sqrt{ \frac{1}{\sum w_i^*} }$ of this estimate.
\end{enumerate}

\vspace{0.5cm}
\begin{flushright} \scriptsize Card (2012, Ch.10, p. 234-239)\end{flushright}

---

8) Assessing \textbf{Heterogeneity} among Effect Sizes  

\only<1>{
Heterogeneity is the extent to which effect sizes vary within a meta-analysis.  

It is assessed by means of several indices and methods:
\begin{itemize}
  \item $Q$
  \item $I^2$
  \item $H^2$
  \item Bajaut Plot
\end{itemize}
}

\only<2>{
\small

$$Q = \sum \left( w_i (ES_i - \overline{ES})^2 \right) = \sum (w_i ES_i^2) - \frac{\left( \sum (w_i ES_i) \right)^2}{\sum w_i}$$

\begin{itemize}
  \item $w_i$ is the weight of study $i$.
  \item $ES_i$ is the effect size estimate from study $i$.
  \item $\overline{ES}$ is the mean effect size across studies.
  \item $k$ is the number of studies. \\
  \quad Degrees of freedom: $\chi^2_{df} = k - 1$
\end{itemize}

The \textit{null hypothesis} is that of \textbf{homogeneity}. Hence, a significant $p$ value (e.g., $< .05$) \textit{should attest heterogeneity.}

\vspace{0.5cm}
\begin{flushright} \scriptsize Equation 8.6 from Card (2012, Ch. 8) \end{flushright}
}


\only<3>{

\footnotesize

$I^2 = \frac{\tau^2}{\tau^2 + \sigma^2} = 
\begin{cases}
\left( \frac{Q - (k - 1)}{Q} \right) \times 100\% & \text{when } Q > (k - 1) \\
0 & \text{when } Q \leq (k - 1)
\end{cases}
$

\begin{itemize}
  \item $\tau^2$ is the estimated between-study variability.
  \item $\sigma^2$ is the within-study variability.
  \item $Q$ is the statistic computed for significance tests of heterogeneity.
  \item $k$ is the number of studies.
\end{itemize}

\textbf{Suggestions of Huedo-Medina et al. (2006)} regarding the amount of heterogeneity:
\begin{itemize}
  \item $I^2 \approx 25\%$ small
  \item $I^2 \approx 50\%$ medium
  \item $I^2 \approx 75\%$ large
\end{itemize}

\vspace{0.5cm}
\begin{flushright} \scriptsize Equation 8.7 from Card (2012, Ch. 8) \end{flushright}
}

“The value of H = 1 represents complete homogeneity. So theoretically it ranges from one to infinite. Further, for assessing significance of heterogeneity, if the 95\% CI of H statistic does not involve the null value (i.e., one), heterogeneity becomes significant at 5\% level of significance. There is no universal rule to grade H2 in mild, moderate or severe”  

\vspace{1cm}
\tiny
Equations and text from Pathak, Dwivedi, Deo, Sreenivas, \& Thakur (2017, p. 16, \textit{Biostatistics and Biometrics Open Access Journal})
\end{columns}
}

9) Explaining Heterogeneity among Effect Sizes: \textbf{Moderator Analyses} (e.g., meta-regression and subgroup analysis)

\small

If a meta-analysis reveals significant heterogeneity among effect sizes, the next step is to explain this variability using additional variables collected during the coding of the primary studies.

There are two main strategies to account for heterogeneity among effect sizes:
\begin{itemize}
  \item \textbf{Meta-regression:} used when continuous variables are employed to explain heterogeneity (e.g., using the variable “average age” to account for variability in effect sizes).
  \item \textbf{Analysis of categorical moderators:} used when categorical variables are employed to explain heterogeneity (e.g., using the variable “country of origin” to explain differences in effect sizes).
\end{itemize}

10) Assessing the Risk of \textbf{Publication Bias}

\only<1>{
\textbf{Publication Bias} refers to the tendency for studies reporting significant or expected effects to be more likely to be published than those reporting null or unexpected results.
\begin{center} Studies that should be included in the meta-analysis \end{center}
\begin{figure}
  \centering
        \includegraphics[width=1\linewidth]{figs/PublBias_studies.png}
\end{figure}
}

\only<2>{
Strategies:
\footnotesize
\begin{itemize}
  \item \textbf{Moderator analysis} of published \textit{Vs} unpublished studies
  \item \textbf{Funnel Plot} (Sterne \& Egger, 2001): see the next slide
  \item \textbf{Egger’s linear regression method} (Egger, Davey, Smith, Schneider, \& Minder, 1997) and the \textbf{Begg and Mazumdar’s (1994) rank correlation method} are two tests of the asymmetry of a funnel plot (significant results = potential publication bias)
  \item Failsafe numbers (\textbf{Failsafe \textit{N}}): the number of excluded studies, all averaging an effect size of zero, that would have to exist for their inclusion in the meta-analysis to lower the average effect size to a nonsignificant level. A \textbf{failsafe \textit{N} > 5\textit{k} + 10} supports findings’ robustness
  \item \textbf{Trimm and Fill method}: imputes “missing” studies to create a more symmetrical funnel plot. If trivial differences between the observed and the new estimated effect sizes were observed, then publication bias (albeit present) should not be a serious threat to our results (Duval, 2005).
\end{itemize}
}

# Other Topics

\only<1>{
The \textbf{Individual Participant Data (IPD) Approach}: Rather than extracting summary data from study publications, original research data are sought directly from the researchers responsible for each study (Debray et al., 2015).  
\begin{itemize}
  \item PROS = more reliable results, given the possibility to run further analyses
  \item CONS = very time consuming!!
\end{itemize}
}

\only<3>{
\textbf{Overview of Reviews}
\begin{itemize}
  \item ``Synthesizes findings from existing systematic reviews to provide a higher-level synthesis of evidence.''
\end{itemize}
\textbf{Scoping Reviews}
\begin{itemize}
  \item ``Maps the breadth and scope of literature on a topic without necessarily appraising or synthesizing findings.''
\end{itemize}
\textbf{Evidence and Gap Map (EGM)}
\begin{itemize}
  \item ``Identifies where research exists and where gaps remain, providing a visual representation of research coverage rather than synthesizing findings.''
\end{itemize}
